en.purpose: To assess Rome IV Diagnostic Criteria for Child Non-retentive Fecal Incontinence.
en.use: Used for children aged 4 years and older, as well as adolescents. All criteria must be fulfilled to get positive diagnostic result.
en.misuse:
Patients who exhibit any of the following alarm features should undergo clinical evaluation for alternative diagnoses, even if non-retentive fecal incontinence is present: 
- physical examination findings that suggest structural disease (fistulous opening, absent anal or cremasteric reflex, decreased lower extremity strength/tone/reflexes, abnormalities of the back (such as hair tuft, gluteal cleft deviation, sacral dimple, anal tenderness or tags))
- anal scars
- hematochezia or melena
- abdominal distension
- vomiting
- urinary retention or incontinence.

gt0001.text: Rome IV Diagnostic Criteria for Child Non-retentive Fecal Incontinence Assessment
gt0001.description:
The Rome IV criteria offer symptom-based guidelines for diagnosing disorders of gut-brain interaction (DGBI) in children and adolescents, including nonretentive fecal incontinence. Earlier versions of the Rome criteria relied primarily on expert consensus, as research on DGBI in this population was still limited.

The diagnosis of nonretentive fecal incontinence should be based on clinical history, specific symptom criteria, physical examination, and minimal diagnostic testing when clinically indicated. These criteria are used to establish the diagnosis in children and adolescents presenting with fecal incontinence.

gt0004.text: Defecation in places inappropriate to the sociocultural context

gt0006.text: After appropriate evaluation, the fecal incontinence cannot be explained by another medical condition

gt0007.text: The symptoms have lasted for at least one month.
